text:
I have been working almost exclusively as a thought leadership ghostwriter for over a year now and here are 3 things that helped me write perfectly for CEOs(not already mentioned in this thread)—

1. Understanding the core ideas these CEOs build bigger ideas around and echoing them in all content pieces.
For example, a CEO that is a sustainability advocate will talk a little about sustainability even when writing about financing. ‘Not monitoring personal expenditure is a deeply unsustaible way to gauge your finances. It leads to wastage of monetary resources that could otherwise have been deployed elsewhere.’ 

The idea is to understand what this person cares about on a personal front as and then frame content from that _perspective_ not just the language. 
This takes time and exposure to multiple long form formats but is achievable over time.

2. Printing out edits from my editor/strategist > grouping changes under sub heads such as ‘tone’, ‘clarity’ and ‘context’ and then narrowing down on the tone parameters. 
Initially this seems like a lot of work but in my experience it’s the only way to get better much quicker. 

3. It was great when I got speaking and writing samples but what was better was when I was given the context as well. 
For example if a CEO is addressing fundraising in a speaking sample is the target to help an audience of founders raise funds or to educate a university class on fundraising? 

This context will monumentally change the way the CEO talks. 

I know I’m a little late to the thread but I hope this helps!

Initially this seems like a lot of work but in my experience it’s the only way to get better much quicker.

3. It was great when I got speaking and writing samples but what was better was when I was given the context as well. 
For example if a CEO is addressing fundraising in a speaking sample is the target to help an audience of founders raise funds or to educate a university class on fundraising?
This context will monumentally change the way the CEO talks.
I know I’m a little late to the thread but I hope this helps!

text: <@U02AR2XSN1M> I like all of the ideas above. When it comes to company news like this, I usually look for the "so what?" So could you frame this anniversary/milestone around a big idea or word? 40 years of X? Look ahead at a big initiative they're moving into as they go into the next 40 years? I'd try to hook some kind of idea onto the milestone so it's about more than the milestone itself. Hope that makes sense.

text:
Hi Adrienne - We are doing something very similar in house right now. We structured 2-part workshops for each executive. The first one was purely focused on defining the execs' "thought leadership persona," so we asked them to bring examples of writers / experts they like. We unpacked those, along with doing some free association of modifiers they would use to describe themselves and those they want to steer clear of.

We wrapped up with a quick, fun exercise where execs had to take a stance on a Very Important Question (e.g., "is a hotdog a sandwich?" "are cupcakes superior to cake?") It was kind of silly, but allowed us to see how each person formulates opinions and arguments.

elements.text:

We unpacked those, along with doing some free association of modifiers they would use to describe themselves and those they want to steer clear of.

We wrapped up with a quick, fun exercise where execs had to take a stance on a Very Important Question (e.g., "is a hotdog a sandwich?" "are cupcakes superior to cake?") It was kind of silly, but allowed us to see how each person formulates opinions and arguments.

text:
<@U02AR2XSN1M> I love the above options. I also want to suggest that you make this an opportunity to give back and centre the concrete ways in which the company supports the community, takes direct action and is aligned with the marathon that is decolonizing business.

This could be a significant time to demonstrate that it's actually not "business as usual" that will propel the company another 40 years. No performative action, only consistent and deliberate commitments to shifting power and building equity.

text:
My default is as you mentioned in your post. To avoid as much navel-gazing as possible. Celebrate a few big milestones/wins/hiccups, but mostly talk about the customers and their success as much as possible.

ie. Over 40 years we’ve grown X amount, hit Y milestones, hit speed bumps A, B, C as well, etc But along the way all of this has contributed to, customer Z growing their business 200%, adding 40 employees and started serving international clients. We’re proud to have been an integral part of their journey of growth….

+ a lot of what was already mentioned above.

text: Quick question: What is the ideal length for a webinar? 30 mins? 45 mins? 1 hr? 2 hrs? Let me know in this thread. :point_down:

elements.text: Quick question: What is the ideal length for a webinar? 30 mins? 45 mins? 1 hr? 2 hrs? Let me know in this thread.

text:
I initially wanted to say “it depends” because it ultimately boils down to the quality of content and level of engagement. After all, we sit through 2 1/2 hour movies and binge entire seasons of a show in one sitting.

But it really boils down to what the audience expects from a “webinar.” Most webinars are around one-hour long, so we anticipate something in that ballpark and balk at the notion of a webinar that lasts multiple hours. But our expectations for a “virtual event” can run multiple days.

elements.text:

But it really boils down to what the audience expects from a “webinar.” Most webinars are around one-hour long, so we anticipate something in that ballpark and balk at the notion of a webinar that lasts multiple hours. But our expectations for a “virtual event” can run multiple days.

text: great point

elements.text: great point

text:
I have done plenty of this thought leadership writing before and it is tricky. Even if you think you nailed it, you end up missing the mark a bit. And part of that is because a person's voice is so personal to them that it will be nigh impossible to match what they have in their head.

I try to absorb lots of written material, but also videos and conversations. I try to peep into how they communicate with their team. All of it.

I really like someone's point above about having the execs give it a final voice edit!

elements.text:

I try to absorb lots of written material, but also videos and conversations. I try to peep into how they communicate with their team. All of it.

I really like someone's point above about having the execs give it a final voice edit!

elements.text: This one!

text:
In my experience, I’ve found that 30 mins + 15 mins left at the end for q&a gets the most engagement and people stay until the end.

Personally though, I agree with Ronnie - if you set my expectations in the marketing (lunch & learn vs webinar vs workshop vs virtual event) and ensure there is value for the entire duration, I’ll stay no matter how long it is.
